objinfo.printdate: 1795The characteristics of the color printing indicate that this impression is the first one printed from the larger matrix in 1795. The second impression in this printing is *Pity* in the Tate Collection (Butlin 310); the third impression is in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York (Butlin 311).
objinfo.objsize: 41.6 x 51.3 cm.The print has been trimmed, particularly along the left edge.

provenance.note: Perhaps acquired by Blake's wife, Catherine, upon his death in 1827; perhaps acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Mrs. Blake's death in 1831; the dealer Joseph Hogarth, who offered the print, with the assistance of George Richmond, to John Ruskin c. 1843; at least briefly in Ruskin's possession, but probably returned to Hogarth; acquired c. 1878-80 by Arthur Burgess; J. W. Pease, probably no later than 1888; bequeathed by J. W. Pease to Miss S. H. Pease in 1901; her executor, Lord Wardington; offered Christie's, 2 Dec. 1938, lot 56 (apparently bought-in by Lady Wardington at é56.14s.); offered Sotheby's, 28 Nov. 1974, lot 137 (not sold, but acquired immediately after the auction by the Oxfordshire book dealer Colin Franklin); offered in Franklin's 1977 *Catalogue of Early Colour Printing* for $30,000; acquired in 1977 by Paul Mellon, who gave the print to the Yale Center for British Art in the same year.

objnote.p: "Pity" illustrates lines from Shakespeare's "Macbeth," Act 1, Scene 7: "And Pity, like a naked new-born babe,/ Striding the blast, or heav'n's cherubin hors'd/ Upon the sightless couriers of the air...." The closed eye of the horse suggests that Blake has transposed sightlessness from the observer (one who cannot see the wind) to the observed (blind horses). The design would seem to be a positive image of compassion, but some of Blake's writings of the 1790s indicate that it is only the useless product of a fallen condition. As he writes in "The Human Abstract" in "Songs of Experience," "Pity would be no more,/ If we did not make somebody Poor" (Erdman page 27).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two figures, one of whom holds a baby, ride back-to-back on a horse and soar above a supine woman below. The horse extends at least one front leg, and both hind legs, horizontally in a posture suggestive of leaping, striding, or flying. The horse's mouth is open; a rein extends from it and loops over the horse's neck. Its mane flies forward and its tail streams backward and up. The front-most figure, one of Shakespeare's "cherubin" (angels), wears a gown that covers her lower body, sits on the horse with her right leg drawn up, but turns her upper body to face the viewer. With both of her arms, she reaches down to hold the child, who stands with his right foot on the fingertips of her left hand. With her right hand she supports the child. Her flame-like hair stands on end, angled to the left. She may be looking down toward the woman lying below, or perhaps toward the child. The child faces away from the viewer, but bends its head and body backwards to look up towards the female who holds him. The child’s right leg is extended down and back; its left leg is not pictured. Its arms are raised horizontally (or between the horizontal and 135 degrees) with palms out and up. Behind the front-most female figure, and facing away from the viewer, is another figure of uncertain gender (more likely male than female?) with semi-long hair. This figure’s upper body is nude, but the drapery streaming out behind him suggests that a gown covers his lower body. His arms are extended horizontally with palms down. Beneath the horse and the figures above lies a supine, gowned female with long, curly hair. Her arms are bent at the elbows and her hands clasped on her breast with fingers interlinked in an attitude of prayer. Her head is bent back in a limp posture. Her eyes are open, pupils raised. The horse flies over clouds. Slanting lines of rain fall from the clouds at right. The woman lies on the ground, which may be covered with low-growing vegetation (grass, moss, or lichens). The background is dark; this is certainly a stormy scene, and may be a night scene. Two other impressions of this color print picture two horses, but there is no clear evidence of a second horse in this impression.

component.illusobjdesc: The front-most female figure in the upper part of the design, whose lower body is draped with a gown, rides a horse. She is probably one of the "cherubin" (that is, angels) in the text illustrated (Shakespeare's Macbeth). Her right leg is drawn up, her lower body faces to the right, and she turns her upper body to face the viewer. With both of her arms, she reaches down to hold the child, who stands on one foot on the fingertips of her left hand; she supports the child with her right hand. Her long, flame-like hair stands on end, angled to the left. She may be looking down and to the left, toward the woman lying below, or perhaps toward the child. Her bare right foot is prominent. She sits on a blanket draped over the horse’s back.

A nude male child or infant with short, curly hair stands (or hovers) with his right foot on tiptoe on the fingers of the central female figure. The child faces away from the viewer, but bends its head and body backwards to look up in right profile towards the female who holds him. His mouth may be slightly open. The child’s right leg is extended down and back; his left leg is not pictured. His arms are raised horizontally (or between the horizontal and 135 degrees) in a cruciform posture with palms raised up and out. The fingers of the right hand are slightly spread. The child probably personifies pity in the passage illustrated from Shakepseare's Macbeth.

Behind the front-most female figure, and facing away from the viewer, another figure is pictured, apparently riding on or hovering behind the horse. This figure's gender is uncertain, but is more likely male than female. His hair is between long and short. He is probably one of the "cherubin" (that is, angels) in the text illustrated (Shakespeare's Macbeth). This figure's upper body is nude, but the drapery streaming out behind him suggests that a gown covers his (unpictured) lower body. His arms are extended horizontally with palms down.

A horse soars above the supine female figure. The horse has at least the right front leg and both hind legs extended horizontally. The horse has its right eye closed, or perhaps it is blind in accord with Blake's response to the text illustrated ("sightless couriers"). The horse's mouth is open; a rein extends from its mouth and loops over its neck. The horse's mane flies forward, and its tail streams backwards and up. The horse has a blanket draped over its back, visible to the left of its rider. A small tassel decorates its corner. Two other impressions of this color print picture two horses, but there is no clear evidence of a second horse in this impression.

Beneath the horse and the figures above lies a supine female with long, curly hair whose head is bent back limply. She may be the mother of the new-born child above. Her arms and shoulders are bare, but a gown covers the rest of her body and wraps around her feet, almost like a shroud (although she is probably not dead). Her arms are bent at the elbows and her hands clasped on her breast with fingers interlinked in an attitude of prayer. Her eyes are open, with pupils raised.

The horse flies above (and probably in front of) clouds. Slanting lines of rain fall from the clouds at right. A wind apparently blows from left to right (this may account for the forward angle of the horse's mane). The background of this stormy scene is dark; it may be night.
The supine woman may be lying on low-growing vegetation, such as grass, moss, or lichens.
